basics.name: Seongmin Lee
basics.label: Scientist
basics.summary: A postdoctoral researcher at UCLA's SEAL lab, specializing in scalable program analysis and statistical software testing

education.institution: Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
courses: Double major in Department of Mathematical Sciences

Academic Positions.name: UCLA
Academic Positions.summary: Working as a postdoctoral researcher at UCLA's SEAL lab, focusing on statistical software engineering.

Academic Positions.name: Max Planck Institute for Security and Privacy (MPI-SP)
Academic Positions.summary: Worked as a postdoctoral researcher at MPI-SP's Software Security group, focusing on statistical software testing and program analysis.
highlights: Developed estimation techniques for residual risk in software testing.
Contributed to missing mass estimation in statistics, leading to a Spotlight presentation at ICLR 2025.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

Early Career Researcher (ECR) Board.Organization: CASA - Cyber Security in the Age of Large-Scale Adversaries
Early Career Researcher (ECR) Board.Role: The ECR Board decides all funding allocations for the CASA Graduate School (CGS). The board has its own budget and the autonomy to dynamically adapt the programs to the changing needs of ECR members. Representing ECRs in CASA governance, the board organizes activities and meets quarterly to address priorities.

Open Science Ambassador.Organization: Max Planck Institute for Security and Privacy (MPI-SP)
Open Science Ambassador.Role: As representatives of the institute, Open Science Ambassadors raise awareness and provide valuable information to their colleagues about Open Science practices. They meet annually, in person or online, to discuss strategies, participate in workshops, and evaluate the status of Open Science within and beyond the Society.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
